titleInfo.title: Digital Liminality Framework
titleInfo.subTitle: How News Comment Sections Facilitate Identity-Based Liminal Engagement within Politicized Digital Environments

name.namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy

mods:mods.abstract: Online discourse facilitated by information and communication technologies (ICTs) has become a vital aspect of modern political life. Such discourse is heavily valued by politicians, corporations, and other political actors, with digital comment sections serving as popular hotspots of political debate for ordinary people. The comment sections of news sites have become a particularly meaningful host for partisan rhetoric, liminal experiences (temporary, space-specific, and personally impactful processes), and identity development for both conservative and liberal political actors. To investigate the political and uniquely liminal processes that guide this phenomenon, the top stories of two liberal-leaning and two conservative-leaning notable partisan U.S. news websites were collected for 53 concurrent days, as well as the comment sections of these stories, with 200 articles and 9575 comments studied in total. An inductive content analysis of emotional, political, civility and political themes, and chi-square tests of these conversations revealed the significance of "liminal browsing" and online political liminality in driving this phenomenon, while also illustrating specifics on how liminal and collective identities manifest in certain digital spaces. A "digital liminality framework" is established using these findings, one which highlights three key components: accessibility, encouragement, and feedback, as key to digital liminal behavior. I chiefly argue that certain digital spaces should be considered liminal environments in a similar capacity (and political capability) to physical liminal spaces. Collective identity behavior was useful in driving various behavioral trends throughout the sample, but was less impactful than predicted, and especially less influential when compared to liminal identity enactment and behavior, with key differences based on partisan influence. Participants in these forums used these liminal processes as a means of political identity development and attunement with partisan rhetoric, in ways that may not have been possible without the unique aspects of these liminal spaces aiding this process. These findings support the idea that online forums, as liminal spaces, keep ordinary citizens "connected and engaged" to political rhetoric over time, especially when these spaces provide a direct link to emerging political rhetoric. These findings have significance for the development of political culture within digital spaces, the importance of ICT-influenced liminal processes in informing identity development, and the future of the political significance of online forums.
mods:mods.note: A Dissertation submitted to the Department of Sociology in partial fulfillment of the requirements for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy.
Deana Rohlinger, Professor Directing Dissertation; Jennifer Proffitt, University Representative; Koji Ueno, Committee Member; Miranda Waggoner, Committee Member.
